articles.headline: Museums Morph Digitally
articles.snippet: Once reluctant to accept the virtual world, institutions are now using interactivity, 3-D imaging and “augmented reality” in displays.
articles.abstract: Once reluctant to accept the virtual world, institutions are now using interactivity, 3-D imaging and “augmented reality” in displays.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the Metropolitan Museum of Art, a turning point came in 2011. Down went the signs imploring visitors to stow their cellphones. The Met revamped its website, tailoring it for viewing on smartphone screens. The museum was not only allowing visitors to use their mobile phones while browsing the artworks, but encouraging it.

articles.headline: Gone, in an Instant Auction
articles.snippet: Christie’s website now allows customers to buy watches instantly, bypassing the bidding process, as it grows its e-commerce business.
articles.abstract: Christie’s website now allows customers to buy watches instantly, bypassing the bidding process, as it grows its e-commerce business.
articles.lead_paragraph: Right now it’s possible to click on Christies.com and bid on a Warhol drawing, a Helmut Newton photograph and an ostrich Hermès Birkin bag. Often there is a selection of rare wines to be purchased there, too.

articles.headline: Banks Again Avoid Having Any Skin in the Game
articles.snippet: The Dodd-Frank overhaul aimed for banks to make loans with enough “risk-retention” to make them care about repayment, but the final rules appear to fall short of that.
articles.abstract: The Dodd-Frank overhaul aimed for banks to make loans with enough “risk-retention” to make them care about repayment, but the final rules appear to fall short of that.
articles.lead_paragraph: Once upon a time, those who made loans would profit only if the loan were paid back. If the borrower defaulted, the lender would suffer.

articles.headline: Amazon’s Investments Are Piling Up, as Big Losses
articles.snippet: The online retailer was also cautious in its outlook for the fourth quarter, saying it might lose money then.
articles.abstract: The online retailer was also cautious in its outlook for the fourth quarter, saying it might lose money then.
articles.lead_paragraph: The chickens are not coming home to roost at Amazon just yet, but they are checking the flight schedule to Seattle.

articles.headline: Tracing the Line in Colorado, a State Split Left and Right
articles.snippet: Two Democrats, Gov. John W. Hickenlooper and Senator Mark Udall, are in fierce re-election races, and both parties are spending millions in a state not quite red or blue.
articles.abstract: Two Democrats, Gov. John W. Hickenlooper and Senator Mark Udall, are in fierce re-election races, and both parties are spending millions in a state not quite red or blue.
articles.lead_paragraph: ERIE, Colo. — To trace the border between the liberal and conservative corners of the American West, head down East County Line Road, a two-lane asphalt stripe parting the plains here in Northern Colorado.

articles.headline: Investors Are Eager for African Sovereign Debt, Despite Plenty of Risks
articles.snippet: Sub-Saharan countries have raised nearly $7 billion this year, more than in all of 2013, and yields on many bonds have fallen, even with the Ebola outbreak.
articles.abstract: Sub-Saharan countries have raised nearly $7 billion this year, more than in all of 2013, and yields on many bonds have fallen, even with the Ebola outbreak.
articles.lead_paragraph: Five men in dark business suits gathered before Maria Kiwanuka in a semicircle. They were international bankers and they had a pitch to make.

articles.headline: A Plan to Cut Costs and Crime: End Hurdle to Job After Prison
articles.snippet: Cities and states are approving laws that forbid criminal-history questions on most job applications, part of an effort to ease ex-offenders’ re-entry into society.
articles.abstract: Cities and states are approving laws that forbid criminal-history questions on most job applications, part of an effort to ease ex-offenders’ re-entry into society.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — James White had steeled himself for the moment. But when he got to the question on the job application — Have you ever been convicted of a crime? — he shifted nervously in his seat.
articles.byline: By Timothy Williams and Tanzina Vega

articles.headline: Stars Backing Hong Kong Protests Pay Price on Mainland
articles.snippet: Artists backing the pro-democracy movement are being punished by fans and companies in mainland China, on whose support many of their careers depend.
articles.abstract: Artists backing the pro-democracy movement are being punished by fans and companies in mainland China, on whose support many of their careers depend.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — On the night of Oct. 4, at one of the largest pro-democracy rallies in Hong Kong to date, Denise Ho, a local pop singer, performed a new song, “Raise the Umbrella,” a reference to the ubiquitous umbrellas that protesters have used to ward off pepper spray. Tens of thousands waved their lighted cellphones in the air, the crowd ecstatic.
articles.byline: By Amy Qin and Alan Wong

articles.headline: About 25 Europe Banks Are Said to Have Failed Tests
articles.snippet: The results of the review, set to be disclosed on Sunday, are expected to show that some banks have shored up their books, but it could unsettle markets.
articles.abstract: The results of the review, set to be disclosed on Sunday, are expected to show that some banks have shored up their books, but it could unsettle markets.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Around 25 banks failed the European Central Bank’s financial tests, although many of them have already raised capital or made other moves to bolster their books, according to a person with knowledge of the results.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing and Landon Thomas Jr

articles.headline: In Brazil’s Election, a Stark Vote on the Nation’s Economy
articles.snippet: Rarely, if ever, has such a pro-growth, market-friendly candidate emerged as a serious presidential contender in a developing country.
articles.abstract: Rarely, if ever, has such a pro-growth, market-friendly candidate emerged as a serious presidential contender in a developing country.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sunday’s presidential election in Brazil may be too close to call, but investors have already voted with their reais and dollars — and it’s Aécio Neves in a landslide.
